Climate Change and Carbon Cycling
Measuring and modelling soil carbon dynamics

Soils play an important role in global climate and as shown by our preliminary work with SOMNET data, there is considerable potential to manipulate soils to offset climate change. Signatory states to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change must provide detailed national emissions inventories that fully report all anthropogenic sources of greenhouse gases. The Kyoto Protocol also allows carbon credits (CO<sub>2</sub> removed from the atmosphere) to be offset against CO<sub>2</sub> emissions, including agricultural soils.
Figure from Falloon and Smith, 2002, Soil Use and Management, 18, 101-111.

We have been developing techniques to apply soil C models at regional and national scales, in order to provide detailed maps of the impacts of changes in climate, land use and management on soil C storage. Our first studies used the RothC and CENTURY models for an area of Central Hungary.  The methodology involves first evaluating the models using datasets from regional long-term experiments at field or site scale, then linking the models to geographic information systems (GIS) or spatial databases of soil, land use and climate for upscaling.
Figure from Falloon et al, 2002, Soil Use and Management, 18, 164-174.

Other recent work at regional and national scales includes the EU MAGEC and LASEE projects. The EU MAGEC project provided modules of soil / plant interactions in agro-ecosystems to contribute to patch (<0.1km) and regional scale (10-100km) modelling frameworks already under development within the EU-TERI programme. In the EU LASSEE project, we used the SUNDIAL model at the regional level to assess the likely impacts of the widespread cessation of inorganic fertilisation in eastern European agriculture on soil sustainability.

More recently, we have been working with the Centre for Ecology and Hydrology and the National Soils Resource Institute to calculate national CO2 emissions inventories for the UK, by developing a National Scale Carbon Model. The IPCC provides a methodology for calculating emissions using defined emission factors. Results from the Rothamsted carbon model (RothC) suggest that the IPCC default values for CO2 may be too high. RothC is now being used to estimate CO2 fluxes from soil under land use change and climate change in the UK, as well as to estimate how changing land management might offset CO2 emissions. The methodology is based on state-of-the art geographic datasets, including a unified soil map for the UK, the national land use map, and current and future climate data. However, such estimates must include the impacts of suggested land use changes on all trace gasses, i.e. N2O and CH4 as well as CO2. Preliminary calculations suggest that this can have a major effect, improving some mitigation options but reducing the impact of others.
Corrine land cover map, used in the project to calculate national CO2 emissions inventories for the UK.

In the EU-ATEAM project, a range of soil and crop models are being used for the European Union, to predict yield under present and future climate and to examine the soil carbon and nutrient dynamics under these conditions. As well as assessing changes in agricultural ecosystem services, we are using these tools to a) predict the likely distribution of bioenergy crops in the future, and b) provide measures of intensity of land-use for input to the biodiversity assessment. Preliminary results show that climate change may have significant impacts, but also that there is much scope for adaptation, either by growing different crops or by changing agricultural management, such as crop sowing date. Under a medium-high emissions scenario, yield of some crops may decrease significantly (e.g. winter wheat) whilst carbon and nitrogen losses from the soil may also increase. However, changes in agricultural management (such as sowing 2 weeks earlier) may reduce these losses.
<I><FONT COLOR=#ff0000>Agroecosystem processes described and predicted by MAGEC (below dotted line) and those generic processes supplied by ETEMA (above dotted line)
A newly-funded GEF project, Assessement of Soil Carbon Stocks and Change at National Scale, co-ordinated by the University of Reading, is now
working with the RothC and CENTURY models at national scale to improve C sequestration estimates for Brazil, India, Jordan and Kenya.
